facts.text: Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, members of joint Hindu family, owned certain plots of land including Nos. 170 and 74/1 of village Arazi Mafi Pandai.
Mahadeo died leaving widow Basera Kunwar, son Damodar Pande, and daughter Mahura Kuer.
Sahdeo died leaving widow Sundra Kuer.
On death of Damodar Pande, Ram Sewak Pande brought suit against Basera Kunwar and Sundra Kuer for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar Pande, which was dismissed.
On death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande (son of Ram Sewak) and Ganga Pande got names mutated in regard to the property.
Mahura Kuar brought suit for possession of estate left by Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande, decreed on August 1, 1941.
On May 31, 1943, Mahura Kuar obtained possession through court of the estate including plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.
On February 25, 1950, Mahura Kuer applied to Sub-Divisional Magistrate for proceedings under s.145 CrPC against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.
Magistrate ordered attachment of land including plots Nos. 170 and 74/1, possession given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar.
Property under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, comprising part of 1357 F and part of 1358 F.

On December 18, 1950, s.145 proceedings ended in favour of Mahura Kuar, finding her possession established; Adit Pande and Ganga Pande restrained from interfering; attachment ended, possession to be handed to Mahura Kuar.
Opposite party revision to District Magistrate dismissed on March 28, 1951; actual possession delivered in April 1951.
Delivery of possession stayed from December 1950 to April 1951 under District Magistrate's order.
Appellant Raghubansh Lal, Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai, framed khasra of 1358 F for plots Nos. 170 and 74/1, entering name of Adit Pande as in possession in remarks column.
On July 31, 1951, Mahura Kuar filed complaint under s.218 IPC against appellant in Judicial Magistrate Court at Ghazipur.

Case committed to Court of Session; prosecution witnesses: Mahura Kuer (PW1), Gouri Shankar (PW2), Naresh (PW3), who deposed Shubh Karan sapurdar sowed barley and paddy, possession delivered April 1951.
Defence witnesses: Adit Pande (DW1), Ram Swarup (DW2).
Accused plea: Knew from Shubh Karan of s.145 win by Mahura Kuar, but found possession with Adit Pande on spot; did not act per Magistrate order as not received; Mahura Kuar not in actual possession.
Trial court convicted appellant under s.218 IPC, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.200 fine or 4 months RI default.
Allahabad High Court confirmed conviction, relying on statements of Mahura Kuar, Gauri Shankar, Naresh; held entries incorrect to injure Mahura Kuar.
Shubhkaran sapurdar not examined as witness.
Entries in khasra for 1358 F: qabiz badastur (possession as before) in remarks column.
Khasra entries made in March (per evidence).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant, as Patwari, knowingly framed incorrect khasra entries for 1358 F with intent to cause or knowledge likely to cause undue loss or injury to Smt. Mahura Kunwar under s.218 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Accused knew of s.145 order from Shubh Karan but found actual possession with Adit Pande on spot; did not receive Magistrate order; Mahura Kuar not in actual possession; sapurdar Shubhkaran never got possession from Adit Pande.

Absence of Shubhkaran testimony creates doubt; no direct evidence of criminal intent; circumstantial evidence meagre; entry for 1358 F could not cause loss as s.145 decided in Dec 1950, not relevant for s.16 UP Zamindari Abolition Act (which looks to 1356 F).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.218 IPC; s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant deliberately made wrong entries in khasra of 1358 F for plots 170 and 74/1, entering Adit Pande's name in possession in remarks column, knowing incorrect to cause loss to Mahura Kunwar.
Delivery of possession to Mahura Kuar proved by her statement and PW2, PW3; Shubh Karan sowed crops; actual possession in April 1951; accused knew of litigation.

court_reasoning.text: Courts below relied on s.145 proceedings favouring Mahura Kunwar, but land attached and given to Shubhkaran; actual physical possession to Mahura Kunwar only in April 1951; Shubhkaran not examined.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mahura Kunwar not in actual physical possession during attachment period.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution must prove: (1) knowingly framed incorrect record; (2) with intent/knowledge to cause loss/injury to public or Mahura Kunwar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Incorrectness proven, but no direct evidence of intent; circumstantial evidence meagre.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual requires entries per actual facts by inquiry and inspection by April 30.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Patwari responsible for accurate entries based on actual possession.

court_reasoning.text: Entry could not create evidence for s.145 (already decided Dec 1950); not for 1356 F relevant to s.16 Zamindari Act; difficult to see how caused loss.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of public servant framing incorrect record with intent to cause loss/injury.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings establishing possession of Mahura Kunwar.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Records Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs preparation of khasras based on actual facts by Patwari.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems recorded occupant of 1356 F in possession as hereditary tenant; entry complained of is for 1358 F, irrelevant.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of conviction by trial court and High Court set aside; appellant acquitted of offence under s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core legal test for s.218 IPC offence.

key_quotes.text: Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for acquittal: failure to prove mens rea.

key_quotes.text: It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No causal link between entry and injury.
